Fluidized bed oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane to ethylene over VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts: Reduction kinetics and catalyst activity Muhammad Y. Khan a b Sameer Al-Ghamdi c Shaikh A. Razzak a Mohammad M. Hossain a b ⁎ Hugo de Lasa d a Department of Chemical Engineering, King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia Department of Chemical Engineering King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals Dhahran Saudi Arabia b Center of Research Excellence in Nanotechnology, King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia Center of Research Excellence in Nanotechnology King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals Dhahran Saudi Arabia c Research & Development Center, Saudi Aramco, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia Research & Development Center Saudi Aramco Dhahran Saudi Arabia d Department of Chemical & Biochemical Engineering, University of Western Ontario, Canada Department of Chemical & Biochemical Engineering University of Western Ontario Canada ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemical Engineering, King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. Graphical abstract Ethane Conversion and Product Selectivity over the 1.0 Ce Catalyst (feed=2ml, w=0.5g, T=550°C). Cerium-doped γ-Al2O3 (Ce-γAl2O3) catalyst supports are prepared with various amounts of cerium (0.2–5wt.%). An excess solvent impregnation method is used to saturate the vanadium (5wt%) on the cerium-modified supports. The XRD and FTIR characterization techniques indicate the presence of crystalline CeO2 phase, and amorphous VOx phases on the γAl2O3. Raman analysis shows the coexistence of poly-vanadate and mono-vanadate species. BET analysis reveals a high surface area for the synthesized catalysts with a type-IV adsorption isotherm. TPR/TPO analyses show that VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts are very active and stable over repeated reduction/oxidation cycles. The stability/purity of the synthesized catalyst is also confirmed by TGA analysis. NH3-TPD characterization shows mild acidity while the TPR kinetics predicts lower activation energy for reduction. Oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of ethane experiments are developed over VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts under gas-phase oxygen-free conditions in a fluidized CREC Riser Simulator. Temperatures and residence times are varied between 450 and 600°C and 10–50s, respectively. A maximum ethylene selectivity of 87.9% with 10.0% ethane conversion is achieved at 550°C using the 1.0wt.% cerium-doped VOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The successive ethane injections and subsequent catalyst regeneration show the stable redox characteristics of the prepared ODH catalysts. Keywords Fluidized bed ODH Ethane Ethylene Catalyst reducibility Metal-support interaction 1 Introduction Ethylene is an essential raw material for many petrochemical industries. The current worldwide production of ethylene is about 141 million tons per year. Ethylene is mainly consumed in the production of polyethylene, ethylene oxide, ethylene dichloride, ethyl benzene and among others [1]. Furthermore, there has been a steady increase in the demand of the ethylene in last three decades. Thermal cracking and fluid catalytic cracking are the main commercial methods for the production of olefins, including ethylene. This is the case as both conventional routes account for about 70% and 28% of grass olefin production, respectively [2,3]. Typically, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), naphtha, and ethane are feedstocks used in thermal cracking while heavy residue is used in FCC. However, despite the recent advancements, these processes have some serious drawbacks. Thermal cracking is highly endothermic. Thus, it requires a significant heat input to obtain optimum olefin yields. Secondly, large amounts of coke are formed on the furnace tube walls at high tempereavy residue is used in FCC. However, despite the recent advancements, these processes have some serious drawbacks. Thermal cracking is highly endothermic. Thus, it requires a significant heat input to obtain optimum olefin yields. Secondly, large amounts of coke are formed on the furnace tube walls at high temperatures, causing frequent plant shutdowns [3,4]. Catalytic dehydrogenation of paraffin can also be used to produce ethylene. In most of these scenarios, these processes use a fixed bed reactor with a selective catalyst. Typically, alkane molecules react on the catalysts, yielding alkenes along with H2. In this respect, dehydrogenation is an important reaction pathway for propane and butane conversion. However, dehydrogenation is not feasible in the case of ethane, due to the high thermodynamic constraints required for ethylene production (temperatures >800°C). Catalytic dehydrogenation also suffers from the other drawbacks such as the high heat input requirement. This is due to the endothermic nature of the reaction, as well as the reaction thermodynamics [5]. To address these issues, alternative methods for olefins production are being considered, and among alternative routes, oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) reactions are important with their operations occurring at lower temperatures [5–8]. However, and to be able to implement these alternative methods for ODH, one should develop more selective catalysts. This should also be done in order to considerably reduce the undesired formation of side products such as COx (CO and CO2), oxygenated hydrocarbons and acids along with olefins and H2O [7]. In this regard, several metals, metal oxides, mixed metal oxides and even metal chlorides have been tested for the ODH of ethane, both in the presence as well as in the absence of gas-phase oxygen [5,7–10]. Metal oxides include alkali and alkaline based earth metal oxides [10–12]. Most recently, transition metal oxides are being investigated for ethane ODH. This is due to the ease with which they are oxidized, reduced, and to their multiple oxidation states. Excellent examples are VOx, MoOx, NbOx, TiO2, Zr2O3 [13–16]. VOx has been investigated as an active catalyst for ODH reactions given its dual catalytic nature. However, its low reactivity has been reported [8,9]. VOx can be impregnated on a diversity of support materials. Among them are SiO2 [12], TiO2 [12–14], ZrO2 [13], and Al2O3 [14,16,15]. An excellent example is the 10wt.% VOx/cAl2O3 catalyst, which is a fluidizable catalyst under gas-phase oxygen-free conditions [17]. This catalyst yields a 6.5–27.6% ethane conversion with 57.6-84.5% ethylene selectivity in the 550–600°C range. Furthermore, multimetallic oxides have been extensively used in ODH reactions. For instance, MoVTeNbO is reported to be one of the most active and selective catalysts for the ODH of ethane to ethylene. It is reported that the vanadium species play an active catalytic role in these multimetallic catalysts, with Mo and Nb improving vanadium activity [11,18–20]. Other examples of multimetallic catalysts are the following: MoVNbO [21], MoVNbPdO [22], MoVAlO [23], MoVNbOTiO2Pd [24], MoVAlTiO [25], MoVNbTeO/α-Al2O3 [19], MoVAlO [26], and CsFe3+HPVMoO [27]. Regarding ODH catalyst performance, enhancement modifiers are being considered, with these being either doped or physically impregnated on the catalyst support. Typical modifier examples are the following: Ca, Mg, Cl, Br, Ni, Nb, Cu, Au, Si, Ce, Zr [28]. Furthermore, cerium has been considered as a support modifier, given its three-way catalytic nature [29]. In fact, it has been reported that cerium tends to increase the thermal stability of the ODH catalyst, reducing catalyst deactivation. This is due to its unique oxygen storage/release characteristics, and its redox nature. These properties have enabled its usage in pollution control, absorption, deep combustion, gas detection and in fuel cells [29–33]. For example, it has been reported that the addition of Ce to NiO2 catalysts improves the ethane ODH catalyst activity [34]. In spite of the progress reported, there is a need for highly selective ODH fluidizable catalysts, operating under a gas-phase oxygen-free atmosphere [32]. Given that the lattice oxygen should drive ODH reactions, one can anticipate that catalyst reducibility will yield enhanced ethylene selectivity [17,35–39]. To accomplish this, Ce was doped on a γ-Al2O3 support. This was followed by VOx impregnation on the Ce modified γ-Al2O3 support, as proposed in our previous contribution [37]. It is anticipated that this catalyst preparation approach will determine both the type and the fraction of VOx phases, as well as the VOx reducibility [40]. It is also expected that cerium will moderate catalyst reducibility, depressing non-selective oxygen reactions. In order to establish the value of the proposed ODH catalyst, experimental runs were developed in a fluidizable bed CREC Riser Simulator reactor [41,42]. These experiments demonstrated the high selectivity and stability of the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts for successive ODH experiments. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In this work, both pure γ-Al2O3 and Ce-modified γAl2O3 catalyst supports were prepared. The supports were synthesized by following the experimental procedure reported by X. Shang et al. (2012) and J. Wang et al. (2013) [43,44] and that also used in our previous work [37]. In this surfactant-free approach, γ-Al2O3 was prepared by dissolving an Al-precursor salt (Al(NO3)3·9H2O) in deionized water. This Al solution was then partially hydrolyzed in a 1M ammonium carbonate solution, under vigorous stirring. This was done until the formation of a polymeric gel having a pH of 5.3. The gel was dried in the oven at 30°C for 24h. It was then aged at 150°C and 200°C, each for a 12h interval, at the temperature ramp of 1°C/min. Finally, the dried samples were calcined at 300°C, for 12h at the heating rate of 1°C/min. A similar synthesis method was used for the preparation of the cerium-modified support (Ce-γAl2O3). However, in this case, before the hydrolysis step, an appropriate amount of cerium-precursor (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O) (0.2, 1, 3, & 5wt.%) was added to the Al-precursor solution. The calcination temperature was set to 400°C for 6h. Besides these modifications, the remaining synthesis method was exactly the same. An equal amount of 5wt.% of VOx was dispersed on all Ce-γAl2O3 supports as described above by using an “excess” solvent impregnation method under vacuum conditions. In this typical impregnation method, 5wt.% of vanadium was saturated on the modified supports. The equivalent amount of vanadium acetylacetonate was dissolved in an excess amount of toluene. The Ce-γAl2O3 support was then added to the resultant VOx-precursor solution under vigorous stirring conditions. The solution was stirred for 6h under the vacuum mode and was then filtered. After the filtration, the solid residue was allowed to dry at room temperature for 24h. It was then, dried further for 6 more h in a furnace at 140°C, at a temperature ramp of 0.5°C/min. The dried powder catalyst was then reduced in a fluidizable bed reactor using a reducing gas mixture of 10% H2 and 90% Ar. Finally, the catalyst was oxidized in the furnace at 750°C for 8h, at a temperature ramp of 0.5°C/min. For the sake of simplicity, the nomenclature given in Table 1 will be adopted in the upcoming sections. The amount given in Table 1 is calculated in accordance with the amounts of preparation process. The measured particle size of the synthesized catalyst is ranging from 15 to110μm, with a Sauter mean diameter of 95μm. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 X-Ray diffraction (XRD) XRD was conducted to identify the relative concentration of the crystalline phases present in the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts. Mini-Flex II benchtop XRD equipment from Rigaku with a Cu-Kα radiation source was used to analyze the prepared catalysts and supports. The other operational parameters were set as wavelength=0.15406nm, voltage=30kV, current=15mA and in the 2θ range of 10–90° with a normal scan rate of 3°/min and a step size of 0.02. 2.2.2 N2 adsorption analysis The N2 adsorption analysis of the synthesized γ-Al2O3 support and the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalyst were conducted to determine their BET specific surface area and pore volumes. BET experiments were performed in a Quantachrome ASIQwin instrument equipped with a liquid nitrogen bath to keep the temperature at 77K for nitrogen adsorption. In each experiment, before the analysis, approximately 0.45g of the catalyst sample was initially degassed at 350°C, for 2h under a N2 flow. The adsorption isotherms were measured in the relative pressure range of 10−4–1. 2.2.3 Thermogravimetric analysis TGA technique was used to check the physical and chemical stability of the catalyst as a function of the increasing temperature. Low boiling chemical species in the catalyst evaporated and appeared as a peak in the plot of derivative weight loss vs temperature. The TA SDT-Q600 model of the TGA equipment was used for this analysis. The selected operating parameters were: a) A heating ramp of 10°C/min, b) A weight of the sample of 15mg, c) A temperature range of 25–1000°C and d) A N2 purging rate of 100cm3/min. 2.2.4 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectra were recorded using Horiba Raman spectrometer (iHR 320) with CCD detector, which eliminates the elastic beam scattering. The excitation wavelength of 532nm with the laser intensity of 50% at 50–2500 spectrum was used in all the cases. All the catalysts were dehydrated at 500 oC for 1h before their spectra collection. 2.2.5 Temperature programmed reduction and oxidation (TPR/TPO) The reducibility and maximum reduction temperature for the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts were analyzed by TPR characterization. The repeated TPR/TPO analyses also assisted in measuring the catalyst stability. The TPR experiments were performed in the Micromeritics AutoChem-II using a reducing gas mixture of H2/Ar (5/95wt.%). Prior to the reduction of the catalysts, the samples were pretreated in an Ar (99.9%) flow rate of 50cm3/min, at 300°C for 3h. After the cooling of pretreated samples to the ambient temperature, the bed temperature was gradually raised to 850°C, at the heating rate of 10°C/min, in presence of the reducing gas mixture (50cm3/min). The thermal conductivity detector (TCD) measured the concentration of the exiting H2 gas, and hence the catalyst reduction. The total H2 consumption was calculated by finding the area under the H2 concentration curve (TCD signal versus time plot). 2.2.6 Temperature programmed desorption NH3-TPD analysis is widely used to determine the total acidity, the strength of the acidic sites, and the metal support interaction. TPD experiments were also performed using the Micromeritics AutoChem-II Analyzer equipment. For each experimental run, approximately 100mg of the sample was placed in a quartz U-tube, flushed under a helium flow rate of 30cm3/min for 3h, at 300°C. After this degassing step, the bed temperature was brought back to 100°C and was saturated with a 5% NH3 (balanced He) gas mixture for 1h, at the flow rate of 50cm3/min. The non-adsorbed NH3 molecules between the catalyst particles were then removed by the helium circulated over the catalyst bed, at a flow rate of 50cm3/min, for 1h. The NH3 desorption was recorded with a TCD detector, by raising the sample temperature to 750°C, with a temperature ramp of 10°C/min. 2.2.7 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) FTIR characterizes the infrared spectrum of absorption, the transmission and/or the photoconductivity through a solid or liquid. This is done to determine the nature of the functional groups attached to a particular support. FTIR analyses of the prepared samples were conducted by using a Nicolet 6700 Thermo Fisher Scientific equipment. For each experimental run, 3mg of the catalyst was thoroughly mixed with 400mg of standard KBr. The resultant FTIR spectrum was recorded in the range of 400–4000cm−1. 2.3 ODH of ethane reactions The gas phase oxygen free ODH experiments of ethane over the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts were conducted in a CREC riser simulator batch reactor as shown in Fig. 1 (a). This lab-scale batch reactor (53cm3) is designed for the evaluation and kinetic studies of catalysts under fluidized bed conditions (riser/downer) [41]. The reactor section consists mainly of two parts: a) the upper section, and b) the lower section. The overall reactor assembly has the following key components: a) an impeller, b) retaining rings, c) grids, d) thermocouples, e) heaters, and f) a feed injection point. The vacuum box is directly connected to the reactor in order to receive the products through a 4-Port Valve (PV) after a specified reaction time. Following this step, these reaction products are analyzed by an online GC connected to the vacuum box through a 6-PV [45,46]. The entire experimental setup of the CREC Riser Simulator is reported in Fig. 1(b). In each ODH run, the reactor basket was loaded with 0.5g of the catalyst sample. Then, both reactor and vacuum box were flushed with Argon gas and were subjected to the leak test. After confirming that there was no leak in the system, the temperature of the reactor was then gradually raised to the desired temperature level. During this heating process, the system was continuously purged with Argon gas to avoid the interference caused by gas-phase oxygen. The reactor was depressurized to 1atm pressure as it reaches the desired temperature value. When the desired pressure value was reached, the reactor was isolated from the vacuum box by an isolation valve. Upon isolation, the vacuum box pressure was further reduced to 20.7kPa (3.75 psi) with the help of a vacuum pump. After the depressurization step, the catalyst was fluidized by rotating the impeller which is located just above the reactor basket, at a speed of 4000rpm. At this time, the reactor was ready for the injection of the feed. This feed (ethane) was injected into the reactor with the help of the preloaded airtight syringe. After a pre-specified reaction time, the 4-PV automatically opened. This allowed the reaction products to be transferred to the vacuum box and subsequently be collected in the loop of a 6-PV. An online GC (Agilent 7890A) equipped with FID and TCD detectors was used to analyze these reaction products from the 6-PV. The product analysis was repeated three times to achieve good accuracy. Ethane conversion, ethylene selectivity, and ethylene yield are defined by Eqs. (1), (2) and (3), respectively: (1) Ethane conversion = ∑ i c i n i Moles of ethane fed × 100 % (2) Ethylene Selectivity = c i n i ∑ i c i n i × 100 % (3) Ethylene Yield = Ethane conversion % × Ethylene Selectivity % 100 where, ci is the number of carbon atoms in gaseous carbon containing products i, and ni are the moles of carbonaceous products i. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 X-ray diffraction Fig. 2 illustrates typical XRD patterns of the calcined γ-Al2O3 support and the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalyst samples. A pure γ-Al2O3 support gives diffraction peaks in the 2θ scale at 37.0°, 45.5°, and 67.0°. According to the JCPDS card 10-0425, these peaks are assigned to pure γ-Al2O3 [43]. The 0.2 Ce catalyst shows no XRD peaks for the CeO2. Thus, one can conclude that at this level of Ce doping, the γ-Al2O3 crystalline framework is almost maintained due to the presence of the amorphous CeO2 phase. However, as the dopant wt.% is increased from 0.2wt.% to 5wt.%, clear distant peaks appear, indicating the formation of crystalline CeO2. In these higher cerium-doped catalysts, the γ-Al2O3 XRD peaks decrease, becoming part of the XRD background. This is contrast with the clearly observable CeO2 peaks [32]. Furthermore, as the cerium content in the catalyst is increased, the peak intensities corresponding to the CeO2 phase also become sharper and more intense. These XRD peaks at 28.5°, 33.0°, 47.2°, 56.1°, 58.5°, 76.5 and 79.0° at 2θ, can be assigned to the diffraction lines given by CeO2 fluorite type of cubic crystals (JCPDS 34-0394) [47]. Finally, no diffraction peak is observed for VOx. The absence of VOx peaks is either due to the formation of a highly dispersed amorphous VOx phase and/or to the formation of very small VOx crystallites undetectable to XRD. These findings are in agreement with the technical literature [35,39,48]. Furthermore, there is no evidence of the formation of the solid solution between VOx and alumina. This is due to the absence of AlV3O9 peaks, hence, showing no reaction between the vanadium and Ce-γAl2O3 supports. 3.1.2 BET surface area and pore volume distribution Fig. 3 displays the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm for the bare γ-Al2O3 and for the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalyst. Isotherms have shown in Fig. 3 are type IV adsorption/desorption isotherms, according to the IUPAC nomenclature. That represents the formation of a monolayer, followed by multilayer adsorption and eventually, capillary condensation. It can be seen from Fig. 3 that capillary condensation starts at proximately 0.6 relative pressure. Table 2 lists the BET surface area, the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size and pore volume for the synthesized samples. The surface area of the bare calcined γ-Al2O3 was found to be 296.52m2/g. This high surface area plays the key role in the catalyst activity. After doping the support with cerium and subsequently, impregnating the cerium-modified support with vanadium, yields a decrease of the γ-Al2O3 support specific surface area. Table 2 also reports values BET analyses for the synthesized samples with 95% confidence intervals and cross correlation coefficient R2 >0.99. It can be seen that the higher the loading of cerium, the smaller the BET surface area of the support. This decrease in the surface area is mainly due to the blockage and/or collapse of the pores of the support material with the added wt.% of Ce and VOx. BJH pore volume reduction is also observed with wt.% of Ce and VOx similar to BET surface area. The average pore sizes of the bare γ-Al2O3 support, as well as those of the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts were, in the 2–50nm range. According to IUPAC classification, this can be referred to as a mesoporous geometry [49,50]. Thus, BET analysis not only confirmed the formation of the high specific surface areas of VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts but also established the formation of a mesoporous framework in the catalysts. 3.1.3 TGA analysis TGA experiments of the calcined catalysts is conducted in the temperature range of 30–950°C as represented in Fig. 4 . The TGA curves show a very good stability within the studied temperature range. This observation is consistent to the literature studies as summarized in the review article by Trovarelli in 1996 [51]. There is only one derivative weight loss peak in all of the samples, which appears in the range of 95–120°C. It is assigned to the evaporation of the physically adsorbed water molecules present in the pores of the catalyst [50]. If one compares the curves of the different types of catalysts, it is found that the catalyst having a higher content of cerium (5.0 Ce) shows less weight loss. Hence, it gives a higher thermal stability than the one with lower cerium loading (0.2 Ce). In fact, these results are in full agreement with the published literature which states that presence of CeO2 phase thermally stabilizes the support since it inhibits the γ-Al2O3 sintering and phase inversion to α- Al2O3 at high temperature [51]. 3.1.4 Raman spectroscopy Fig. 5 represents the Raman spectra for the prepared catalyst in 100–1200cm−1 range. MAs support shows no Raman spectra as it is expected due to the ionic nature of the Al-O bond [52]. The appearance of the VOx spectra depends on the vanadium loading and surface concentration of the VOx species. Only a weak spectrum appears at 1130cm−1 for VOx impregnated on the 3.0 Ce catalyst is observed. This transmittance is attributed to the highly dispersed mono-vanadate surface species having isolated tetrahedral structures. 5.0 Ce catalyst also exhibits similar Raman spectra but has a greater intensity of the peak at 1130cm−1. As the ceria content in the support is further increase to 5wt.%, then a secondary weak spectrum at 950cm−1 is also observed and this can be assigned to the V-O-V bond responsible for the crystalline V2O5 formation. This sample shows the coexistence of the both poly-vanadate and mono-vanadate surface species [40]. These results are in complete agreement with the XRD and TPR results that is with the increase in ceria content the dispersion of the VOx decreases which in turn promotes the formation of the crystalline phase of the vanadium oxide. Finally, CeO2 shows Raman spectra at 460cm−1 wavenumber which is more intense in 3.0 Ce and 5.0 Ce catalysts samples, this band is the characteristic of the fluorite-structure CeO2, as also confirmed by the XRD results [53]. 3.1.5 Temperature programmed reduction and oxidation (TPR/TPO) The gas-phase oxygen-free ODH mainly relies on the ease of the removal of the selective lattice oxygen, on the reducibility of the catalyst and on the nature of the oxide phases present on the surface of the catalyst. In this regard, H2-TPR studies can easily demonstrate these important catalytic properties. The nature of the oxide phase formed on the surface of the catalyst depends on several factors such as a) the catalyst synthesis method, b) the type of the active metal oxide, c) the nature of the support material and d) the calcination temperature used during catalyst preparation. The TPR profiles of the calcined VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts with different cerium content are shown in Fig. 6 . The TPR profiles of all samples show an initial large reduction peak at a maximum reduction temperature ranging from 429 to 465°C. The reduction in this temperature range is attributed to the reduction of amorphous monomeric or polymeric VOx phases having an oxidation state between V+5 and V+4 [15,54]. It has been reported by Kašpar et al. (1999) reduction of pure CeO2 phase gives two peaks (low-temperature reduction peak at 497°C and high-temperature reduction peak at 820°C) [29]. Thus, at this temperature range, the surface reduction of the CeO2 phase also takes place and its peak overlaps with the major VOx reduction peaks. Thus overall H2 uptake at low temperature is equal to the summation of the H2 consumed in the reduction of VOx phase and CeO2 phase in the temperature range of 429–465°C [55]. The high-temperature TPR peak appearing at 800°C, is assigned to the bulk reduction of the CeO2 phase only. This high-temperature reduction implies a strong interaction with the support material [56,57]. As the Ce content in the catalysts increase so do their high temperature TPR peak intensities. These TPR peaks are unnoticeable, however, when Ce is lower than 1wt.%. As well, these results are in agreement with the XRD results reported above, showing an increase in CeO2 XRD peaks (see Fig. 2) with cerium content in the catalyst. Another important finding of this analysis is the slight shift of the TPR peaks towards higher temperatures with the overall increase in the cerium content catalysts. Thus, the catalysts doped with more cerium shows the formation of the more stable monomeric surface species, which require higher temperatures to be reduced. This is in contrast with easy to reduce polymeric VOx [55]. These results also confirm that presence of cerium in the catalysts tends to decrease the reducibility of the catalysts [57]. The total amount of H2 consumed was found by calculating the area under the TPR curve. Table 3 reports average H2 uptake of the calcined catalysts which is calculated by averaging the H2 consumed in the five consecutive TPR cycles. One can notice that given the VOx (∼5wt.%) content of all catalysts is almost the same, the total H2 uptake is comparable. The difference in the total consumption of H2 is mainly due to the presence of different amounts of cerium dopant in the catalysts which upon calcination gives CeO2 phase. It’s worth noticing that higher amount of the dopant in the catalysts (more than 1wt.% Ce) decreases the reduction of the VOx phase thus making it more stable phase. On the other hand, catalysts having more cerium content (3.0 Ce and 5.0 Ce catalysts) has comparatively more crystalline CeO2 phase and reduction of this phase increases the overall H2 consumption. Although H2 consumption is greater for higher cerium containing catalysts, but still low cerium containing catalysts (0.2 Ce and 1.0 Ce) are believed to perform better in actual ODH reaction because crystalline CeO2 phase promotes complete oxidation and secondly, the complete reduction of the lattice oxygen of CeO2 requires reaction temperature above 750°C according to TPR Fig. 6. The actual ODH reaction can be easily explained by using TPR/TPO analyses. This is the case because of the resemblance of the reduction of lattice oxygen of the catalyst in the real reactor by ethane with that of reduction of lattice oxygen by H2 in TPR run as shown by the Eqs. (4) and (5), respectively. The reduction of the catalyst by TPR is established by assuming V2O5 is the initial reducible phase of vanadium on the support. The reduction of V2O5 take place via the following reaction: (4) V 2 O 5 + 2 H 2 → V 2 O 3 + 2 H 2 O The selective ODH reaction of ethane over the V2O5 phase of VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalyst is given by: (5) 2 C 2 H 6 + V 2 O 5 → 2 C 2 H 4 + V 2 O 3 + 2 H 2 O Similarly, the reduction of the CeO2 phase of VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalyst during TPR run take place according to the following reaction: (6) 2 CeO 2 + H 2 → Ce 2 O 3 + H 2 O The degree of catalyst reduction can be defined as the ratio of the amount of oxide reduced during a TPR cycle over the total reducible oxide present in that sample. TPR data can be used to find out the percentage reduction of VOx phase as well as CeO2 phase. The percentage fractional amount of reducible oxide can be calculated by using following equation: (7) % f = MW i × V H 2 ν i × V g × ∑ i 2 W i × 100 Where, MWi is the molecular mass of the reducible species (g/mol), V H 2 is the volume of the hydrogen consumed per cycle (cm3 at STP), ν is the stoichiometric coefficient of H2 in Eqs. (4) and (6), Vg is the molar volume of the gas (cm3/mol at STP) and Wo is the initial weight of the species, including both V and Ce (g). Table 3 also reports the% reductions for VOx and CeO2. It can be observed in Table 3 that the degree of reduction of VOx phase decreasing with Ce wt.% which is due to the formation of stable monomeric VOx at higher loading of cerium. However, the degree of reduction of CeO2 phase increases with cerium wt.% which is due to the formation of more reducible surface CeO2 oxide phase that increases the overall reducibility of the catalyst under the hydrogen atmosphere. The% reduction of vanadium can be used to find the nature of the oxide phase present on the surface of the catalyst, also known as the average oxidation state. Table 3 also reports average oxidation states for VOx. For 1.0 Ce catalyst, the average oxidation state is 3.43, with an overall formula of V2O3.43 which is most likely a V2O3 phase. These vanadium surface species have been reported by Al-Ghamdi et al. be a very stable structure among other vanadium oxide phases [39]. Freshly prepared non-calcined 1.0 Ce catalyst was selected in the present study, to further investigate reducibility and re-oxidation capacity over the repeated TPR/TPO cycles as described in Fig. 7 . As can be noticed in Fig. 7, after the first cycle, TPR peaks are slightly shifted toward higher temperatures. Furthermore, H2 consumption also slightly decreases. However, after the second cycle, the H2 consumption, as well as the H2 reduction peak position, become almost constant. Regarding the first cycle, one should notice that the higher H2 consumption in the first cycle, is possibly due to the reduction of residual metal precursors present on the freshly prepared non-calcined catalysts. However, soon after the elimination of reducible nitrates in first TPR cycle, the H2 consumption in subsequent cycle essentially become constant. A similar trend is observed for the reduction temperature which also remains unchanged after first TPR cycle. As a result, repeated TPR/TPO analyses show a good stability of the prepared catalysts, confirming there is no thermal sintering and/or phase transformation during several consecutive redox cycles. 3.1.6 H2 reduction kinetics The overall catalytic reducibility in TPR experiments consists of seven major steps as follows: a). reactant species transport to the pellet outer surface, b) reactant species diffusion into the catalyst inner pore network, c) reactant species adsorption, d) species surface reaction, e) product species desorption, f) product species diffusion from the inner catalyst pore network, g) product species transport from the pellet outer surface [58]. Regarding above-mentioned steps, the external species transport into and from the outer catalyst pellet surface can be neglected. This assumption is valid given that variation in species concentrations in the catalyst surface and bulk phase film is negligible [36,42]. Furthermore, the intraparticle diffusion steps can also be neglected because of the fine size (smaller than 60μm) of the catalyst particles and used. Therefore, the overall TPR rate equation can be considered as a function of the concentration of species in the gas phase, and of the degree of catalyst reduction/oxidation [59]. It can be expressed as: (8) d α dt = k ( T ) f ( α ) f ( P 1 , P 2 ) Where, α is the degree of catalyst reduction, which is an indication of the progress of the reaction; where, k(T) is the reaction rate constant while, P1 and P2 are the partial pressures of the H2 and H2O, respectively. The degree of catalyst reduction ( α ) during each solid-state surface reaction can be expressed as: (9) α = Δ n t Δ n total Where Δn t represents the moles of the hydrogen consumed at time t (min); and Δn total stands for the total moles of H2 consumed in the complete reduction cycle. Given that the TPR/TPO cycles were conducted at the same feed flow rate, therefore, f ( P 1 , P 2 ) in Eq. (8) can be considered as constant. After this modification, the Eq. (8) is simplified to: (10) d α dt = k ( T ) f ( α ) The Arrhenius equation can be used to obtain the reaction rate constant as given below: (11) k ( T ) = k o Exp [ − E app R ( 1 T − 1 T m ) ] Where, R represents the ideal gas constant, ko stands for the pre-exponential factor, Eapp denotes the activation energy and Tm is the centering temperature used to minimize the cross-correlation between the parameters. The function f ( α ) depends on the type of the model used for the determination of reaction kinetics. The amount of H2 consumed during a reduction cycle depends on the availability and type of the reducible metal oxides, which in turn depends on the support material properties. Thus, shape, pore volume, and pore size distribution are the key properties affecting the degree of catalyst reduction. In addition, the active catalyst phases are located at preferred orientations on the support material with this being a function of the chemical nature of the metal support interaction [60]. The function f ( α ) depends on the material properties of the catalyst. According to the Avrami-Erofeev (A-E) model, the reduction/oxidation of the supported active sites proceed via nucleation and crystal growth as represented by the following expression: (12) f ( α ) = n ( 1 − α ) ( − ln [ 1 − α ] ) n − 1 n Where n is the Avrami exponent that shows the reaction mechanism. The Avrami exponent, n=1 shows a random nucleation growth, with n=2 representing 2-D A-E nucleation growth and with n=3 exhibiting 3-D A-E nucleation growth [59,60]. Substituting Eqs. (12) and (11) into Eq. (10) gives the following equation: (13) d ( α ) dt = nk o Exp [ − E app R ( 1 T − 1 T m ) ] ( 1 − α ) ( − ln [ 1 − α ] ) n − 1 n Temperature can be expressed in the form of a heating rate β (°C/min) with a time t in the min as given below:Eq. (14) T = T o + β t By substituting the value of T from Eq. (14) into the Eq. (13), the final form of the TPR reduction equation can be expressed as follows: (15) d ( α ) dt = nk o Exp [ − E app R ( 1 T o + β t − 1 T m ) ] ( 1 − α ) ( − ln [ 1 − α ] ) n − 1 n where T0 is the temperature at the start of the reduction. The above equation was discretized by using a ParametricNDSolve Mathematica function, while a NonlinearModelFit function is used to fit the experimental data. A total of 600 experimental data points was used in the curve fitting. All reduction reactions were started at room temperature with a temperature ramp of 10°C/min. Thus, for the three independent variables (ko, Eapp, and constant of integration) the degree of freedom was 597. This indicated that a considerable amount of data points was used for the estimation of the kinetic parameters. This increased the confidence interval for the estimated parameters. Fig. 8 reports the model predicted versus the experimental degree of catalyst reduction (α) using an A-E model. For n=1, good regression results were obtained. In this case, a random nucleation model was selected for the catalyst reduction. This model showed a very limited crystallite growth formation during the reduction and oxidation cycles. The estimated kinetic parameters, the coefficient of determination (R2) and the Akaike information criterion (AIC) are given in Table 4 . The R2 and AIC values indicate a small variance in the predicted parameters and relatively good quality of the statistical model. VOx species display weak interaction with the γAl2O3 support. Hence, they require less energy for reduction [61–63]. Furthermore, the VOx species on the support are present in different forms and proportions such as a) isolated VOx, b) polyvanadate and c) crystalline forms. Each oxide phase has different reduction activation energies. As a result, it is anticipated that the overall reduction activation energy of the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 samples will be a function of the state of VOx species. Table 4 shows the effect of cerium loading on the activation energies of the freshly prepared calcined catalysts. A gradual increase in the activation energies are noticed with the wt.% cerium in the catalyst. It is also worth noticing that the reduction activation energies of the cerium doped catalysts (0.2 Ce, 1.0 Ce, 3.0 Ce, 5.0 Ce) are lower than the VOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst-free of pro moter or modifier. The activation energies show that the addition of cerium enhances the reducibility of the VOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst by lowering the metal-support interaction Further, the activation energies of the prepared catalysts in the present study are also lower than the VOx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts reported in the literature [42,62]. Thus, in general, VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts require lesser energy for the reduction because of the formation of easily reducible vanadium species. Now if one only compares the prepared cerium modified catalysts (0.2 Ce, 1.0 Ce, 3.0 Ce, 5.0 Ce), 1.0 Ce catalyst has relatively higher reduction activation energy as compared to 0.2 Ce catalyst, showing comparatively stronger interaction between VOx and Ce-γAl2O3 support. These results are in complete agreement with the TPR analyses wherein maximum reduction temperature increased with the wt.% of cerium (see Fig. 6). Having relatively stronger metal-support interaction than 0.2 Ce catalyst, hence one could anticipate that 1.0 Ce catalyst would to be more selective towards olefins formation. An exception to this trend is 3.0 Ce and 5.0 Ce catalysts, regardless of the fact that they also showed higher reduction activation energies but these will not be more selective for ethylene because of presence of higher wt.% of surface CeO2 phase which tends to completely oxides the ethane and ethylene to COx [53,64,65]. Thus, there’s tradeoff between catalyst reactivity and olefins selectivity for these type catalysts. These results also reveal that the activation energy of reduction depends on metal type and metal support interaction. 3.1.7 NH3-TPD analysis Temperature programmed desorption analysis is widely used to determine the metal support interaction, the total acidity, and the strength of the acidic sites. The selectivity of ethylene in a gas-phase oxygen-free ODH reaction mainly depends on these key factors. In fact, a close correlation exists between the acidity of VOx supported catalysts and their catalytic activity [66,67]. The small molecular size and strong basicity of NH3 enables one to investigate the acidity at a broad range of temperatures for the catalysts having pores dimension ≥4Å. The mechanism of the NH3-TPD analysis is based on the sorption strength, which is the sum of the Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites. Therefore, NH3-TPD is unable to differentiate between these two types of acidic sites [67]. In the typical analysis, NH3 is firstly adsorbed at 120°C followed by the ammonia desorption which takes place between 120°C to 750°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. The effluent gas concentration is monitored by the thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Fig. 9 shows the TPD profile for the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts with different amounts of cerium dopant. The total acidity was determined by finding the area under the curve of the TCD signal vs temperature. The total acidity along with the maximum desorption temperature is given in Table 5 . All the samples showed a broad initial NH3 desorption peak with the peak center being at ∼195°C. A higher temperature desorption peak was observed at ∼544°C. The low-temperature desorption peak was assigned to the NH3 desorption from weak and moderate acidic sites. While high-temperature ammonia desorption peak can be assigned to desorption of chemisorbed NH3 from strong acidic sites. The combined effect of both the dopant and active metal oxide (VOx) in the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalyst is to influence the total acidity of the support. In fact, the sample with a higher fraction of dopant shows a slightly higher acidity than the one with lower cerium content. In this respect, Lee et al. and Wu et al. reported that cerium-modified catalyst acidity increases due to the formation of new acidic sites on the support surface [68,69]. Secondly, it was also reported by Al-Ghamdi et al. that the presence of VOx can also increase the concentration of Brønsted acidic sites as compared with the concentration of Lewis acidic site (related with γ-Al2O3) [39]. Therefore, the higher the cerium containing catalyst showed relatively higher total acidity possibly because of the synergetic effect of the formation of new acidic site and promotion of Brønsted sites. 3.1.8 FTIR spectroscopy Fig. 10 shows the FTIR spectra of the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts as having different cerium loadings (0.2, 1, 3, and 5wt.%). All samples give broad spectral bands between 3000 and 3800cm−1 wavenumber and a weak band at 1650cm−1. These bands are assigned to the OH stretching frequency of the adsorbed water and/or are the result of the surface hydroxyl group [70]. The FTIR peaks below 1100cm−1 are attributed to Al-O and VOx bond stretching. Both of these surface oxide species give vibrations at almost the same wavenumber. Ce-O bond vibrations are noted to be in the range of 440–500cm−1 [71]. Finally, FTIR transmittance at 830cm−1 is due to the vibration of the VOV bond bridge. Furthermore, the absorption around 1100cm−1 is assigned to V=O stretching frequency [72]. 3.2 Catalyst activity in the CREC riser simulator Ethane ODH experiments over the synthesized catalysts were conducted under gas-phase oxygen-free conditions in a fluidized bed reactor. Based on the TPR profile, the reaction temperature range was set between 500 and 600°C, while the contact time was varied from 10 to 50s. The temperature of the catalyst was gradually increased from room temperature to the reaction temperature under Argon flushing. After each ODH experiment, the spent catalyst was regenerated with zero air for 10min at 575°C. After this regeneration, the catalyst was flushed with Argon for 15min. The feed to the reactor was pure ethane (99.97% ethane). All ODH experiments were conducted at atmospheric pressure (1atm) and at a constant impeller speed of 4000rpm for the fluidization. All the reactions were conducted using the same feed to catalyst ratio of 2cm3 of ethane/0.5g catalyst. 3.2.1 Effect of catalyst type Fig. 11 a shows the ethane conversion as a function of the type of the synthesized catalysts, each having almost the same content of VOx, but with a varying wt.% of cerium (0.2, 1.0, 3.0, & 5.0wt.%). These experiments were conducted at 550°C, with 10s residence time in gas-phase oxygen-free conditions. The reaction proceeded by using the lattice oxygen of the oxide catalysts. An increase in ethane conversion was observed with the increase in dopant amount. This linear increase in conversion trend confirmed the TPR results (Table 3), where an increase in H2 uptake was observed for the catalysts with higher cerium content. Fig. 11b illustrates the ethane ODH product distribution as a function of the type of catalyst in gas-phase oxygen-free conditions. All these experiments were conducted under the same reaction conditions. The maximum ethylene selectivity of 87.9% was observed with a 1.0 Ce catalyst. In comparison to other catalysts, this catalyst has a mild acidity and a comparable H2 consumption. However, it displays a higher activity than the 0.2 Ce catalyst due to a greater H2 uptake and having more compact surface oxides due to the strong interaction between VOx and support, i.e., higher activation energy of reduction as reported in Table 4. The catalysts having higher H2 uptake (3.0 Ce and 5.0 Ce) than 1.0 Ce catalyst tend to promote complete combustion of feed and products (formation of COx) due to their higher acidity, as revealed by TPD (Table 5). Surprisingly, 5.0 Ce catalyst showed higher ethylene selectivity than that of 3.0 Ce (but lower than 1.0 Ce catalyst). Most likely, the high temperature (800°C) reduction CeO2 species, which has strong interaction with the support material (as explained TPR analysis) [56,57] have contributed to the higher ethylene selectivity of the 5.0 Ce catalyst. A similar trend, in published articles, shows that more acidic catalysts favor the formation of the complete combustion products under the same reaction conditions [17,35,36,73]. Furthermore, it is reported by Martin-Aranda et al., Maldonado-Hodar et al. and Francisco et al. that Ce crystal phases promote combustion reactions [53,64,65]. The abundance of larger crystallites in higher loaded cerium-doped catalysts was confirmed in the present study, by XRD that showed more intense diffraction peaks for the catalyst having higher cerium doping (Fig. 2). Therefore, based on the selectivity of the ethylene, 1.0 Ce catalyst is considered to be the one showing best performance compared to other catalysts. In the subsequent parts of the ODH analysis, only 1.0 Ce catalyst will be subjected to the effects of the reaction temperature and residence time. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction temperature Fig. 12 shows the conversion and product selectivity as a function of the reaction temperature at a constant residence time of 10s. As can be noticed from Fig. 12 that both ethane conversion and ethylene selectivity increase slightly with the increase in the reaction temperature. The maximum selectivity of 87.90% appears at 550°C. Following this, the selectivity decreases slightly while the conversion of ethane continuously increases with temperature. The increase in the selectivity of the ethylene at 550°C, can be explained using the TPD results (Fig. 9) where a major NH3 desorption peak was observed at ∼550°C. Therefore, suggesting that maximum desorption of the ethylene will take place at 550°C temperature, which gives rise to increase its selectivity at this temperature. While, the decrease in the selectivity of ethylene with the continuous increase in ethane conversion after 550°C, can be related to an increased in the amount of secondary reactions that result from the non-selective reaction of ethane and ethylene with the lattice oxygen of catalyst to give deep combustion products (COx). This kind of trend is also observed by Bakare et al., Al-Ghamdi et al. and Elbadawi et al. [17,35,36]. The High mole fraction of COx was observed at the higher reaction temperatures due to easy availability of the lattice oxygen at high temperature [35,39]. Furthermore, the continuous increase in ethane conversion with temperature can be assigned to the ease of catalyst reduction at higher thermal levels, as also observed by an increase in hydrogen uptake in TPR results (Table 3). Thus, the increase in the availability of the lattice oxygen at high temperature tends to activate more CH bonds and gives rise to higher feed conversion [74]. 3.2.3 Effect of residence time The effect of reaction time on the selectivity of the products and on the conversion of the feed at a constant reaction temperature (550°C) is illustrated in Fig. 13 . Conversion increases from 7.63% at 10s to 19.49% at 50s. Therefore, the greater the time that the feed spends in contact with the catalyst, the greater will be the conversion of the feed. Both CO2 and CO have almost constant selectivities at lower contact times. However, at longer residence times both selectivities increase. This increase in the selectivity of the COx is due to the direct combustion of the ethane and non-selective reaction of ethylene with the catalyst lattice oxygen. Furthermore, one can also notice that ethylene selectivity decreases with the contact time, from 87.9% at 10s to 73.4% at 50s. This decrease in ethylene selectivity can be assigned to the non-selective reaction of the produced ethylene with lattice oxygen yielding COx. This typical ODH behavior of ethylene was also reported by Bakare et al., Al-Ghamdi et al., Elbadawi et al., Rahman et al. and Che-Galicia et al. [17,35,36,73,75]. The feed conversion and COx mole fraction are directly proportional to the residence time, while ethylene selectivity is inversely related to it. Thus, there is a trade-off between ethylene selectivity and ethane conversion. Therefore, reaction conditions need to be tuned up to reach optimum ethylene yields. 3.2.4 Ethane consecutive ODH reactions with catalyst regeneration Fig. 14 reports five successive ethane injections over the fresh 1.0 Ce catalyst. After each injection, the spent catalyst was regenerated in the air at 575°C for 10min. All these ODH reactions were conducted at the same operating conditions (contact time=10s and reaction temperature=550°C). The constant ethane conversion and ethylene selectivity over the repeated ODH reactions can be seen in Fig. 14. These experiments not only confirm the stable performance of the synthesized catalyst but also prove reproducibility of the results. These results are also in complete agreement with the repeated TPR/TPO characterization analyses (Fig. 7) that showed the stable catalytic behavior of VOx/Ce-γAl2O3. 3.2.5 Comparison with the literature Fig. 15 shows a comparison of the ODH catalysts of the present study with the best-reported catalysts in our research group. These catalyst evaluations were consistently conducted in all cases under gas-phase oxygen-free condition and using a fluidizable bed reactor. As can be seen, A.H. Elbadawi et al. (2017) reported 9% ethane conversion at the maximum ethylene selectivity of 82% over the VOx/Al2O3-ZrO2 catalyst at the temperature of 525°C [76]. Similarly, Bakare et al. studied the effect of the MoOx doping on a VOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. These authors reported 5–24% ethane conversion and 59.3-68.2% ethylene selectivity at 500–650°C [35]. In a separate study, by Al-Ghamdi et al. vanadium oxide was impregnated on a c-Al2O3 support. This catalyst gave 6.5-27.6% ethane conversion and 57.6-84.5% ethylene selectivity in the 550–600°C range [17]. In the present study, 1.0wt.% cerium doped VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalyst gives 87.9% ethylene selectivity for a 10% ethane conversion. As could be noticed from Fig. 15 that compared to other catalysts, the 1.0 Ce catalyst gives highest ethylene selectivity at relatively much lower reaction temperature of 550°C, showing a 88% ethylene yield with 1.0 Ce catalyst, significantly improved yield as compared to 74% ethylene yield over VOx/Al2O3-ZrO2 catalyst reported by Elbadawi et al. [76]. One should note that the activity of synthesized VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts can be assigned to its high surface area, which provides the elevated density of active sites for ODH. In this respect, the good reactivity of the synthesized catalysts is consistent with the larger H2 uptake and comparatively lower activation energies as calculated by TPR kinetics. As well, the favorable ethylene selectivity can be construed as the synergetic effect of the active amorphous VOx phase and the Ce catalyst dopant, limiting the formation of non-selective oxides for ODH by compacting the losing bound VOx lattice oxygen as revealed by increase in the activation energy for reduction for 1.0 Ce catalyst (Table 4) [29]. In summary, the synthesized fluidizable VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts give high ethylene selectivity, higher catalytic activity, and good stability at low reaction temperature making it a very suitable catalyst for the gas-phase oxygen-free ODH reaction. 4 Conclusions A fluidizable VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalyst was synthesized and was investigated for the gas-phase oxygen-free ODH of ethane to ethylene in a fluidized bed CREC Riser Simulator. Following are the key findings of this work: (i) The XRD and FTIR analyses confirmed the presence of a crystalline CeO2 phase in highly doped VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts. No peak was observed for the crystalline V2O5 phase. (ii) The high surface area of the synthesized γ-Al2O3 support was decreased with the increase in the wt.% of the cerium dopant. (iii) TPR/TPO revealed that VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts are active and give two reduction peaks. Furthermore, the catalysts showed very stable redox behavior over the repeated reduction and oxidation cycles. (iv) TPR reduction kinetics revealed a mild interaction between the catalyst and the support and give comparatively lower reduction activation energies for Ce doped catalysts. (v) NH3-TPD characterization showed both weak and strong acidic sites. NH3-TPD also displayed a total acidity slightly increasing with the cerium loading. (vi) Ethane ODH using the VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalyst was developed in a fluidized bed CREC Riser Simulator. Successive ODH experiments show a stable catalyst with main reaction products being ethylene, CO, and CO2. (vii) An encouraging ethylene selectivity of 87.9% for a 10% ethane conversion, was obtained at 550°C using the 1.0wt.% of cerium doped VOx/γAl2O3 catalyst. As well, an 80% selectivity for a 20% ethane conversion was observed at 575°C and 40s. coredata.dc:description: Cerium-doped γ-Al2O3 (Ce-γAl2O3) catalyst supports are prepared with various amounts of cerium (0.2–5wt.%). An excess solvent impregnation method is used to saturate the vanadium (5wt%) on the cerium-modified supports. The XRD and FTIR characterization techniques indicate the presence of crystalline CeO2 phase, and amorphous VOx phases on the γAl2O3. Raman analysis shows the coexistence of poly-vanadate and mono-vanadate species. BET analysis reveals a high surface area for the synthesized catalysts with a type-IV adsorption isotherm. TPR/TPO analyses show that VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts are very active and stable over repeated reduction/oxidation cycles. The stability/purity of the synthesized catalyst is also confirmed by TGA analysis. NH3-TPD characterization shows mild acidity while the TPR kinetics predicts lower activation energy for reduction. Oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of ethane experiments are developed over VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts under gas-phase oxygen-free conditions in a fluidized CREC Riser Simulator. Temperatures and residence times are varied between 450 and 600°C and 10–50s, respectively. A maximum ethylene selectivity of 87.9% with 10.0% ethane conversion is achieved at 550°C using the 1.0wt.% cerium-doped VOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The successive ethane injections and subsequent catalyst regeneration show the stable redox characteristics of the prepared ODH catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Fluidized bed oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane to ethylene over VOx/Ce-γAl2O3 catalysts: Reduction kinetics and catalyst activity
